greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array read by antidiagonals downwards: T(n,k) is the number of scenarios for the gift exchange problem in which each gift can be stolen at most once, when there are n gifts in the pool and k gifts (not yet frozen) in peoples' hands.
link: Moa Apagodu, David Applegate, N. J. A. Sloane, and Doron Zeilberger, Analysis of the Gift Exchange Problem, arXiv:1701.08394 [math.CO], 2017.
David Applegate and N. J. A. Sloane, The Gift Exchange Problem, arXiv:0907.0513 [math.CO], 2009.
formula: Let A_n(x) be the e.g.f. for row n. Then A_0(x) = exp(x) and for n >= 1, A_n(x) = (d/dx)A_{n-1}(x)/(1-x).
mathematica: t[0, _] = 1; t[n_, 0] := t[n, 0] = t[n-1, 1]; t[n_, k_] := t[n, k] = t[n-1, k+1] + k*t[n, k-1]; Table[t[n-k, k], {n, 0, 9}, {k, 0, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 14 2014, after Maple *)
xref: Main diagonal is A144501. Antidiagonal sums give A144503.
results.author: _David Applegate_ and _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 13 2008
